sn11.10:1.2: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several hermits who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts by the ocean.
sn11.10:1.3: Now at that time a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
sn11.10:1.5: ‘The gods are principled, the demons are unprincipled.
sn11.10:1.6: We may be at risk from the demons.
sn11.10:1.7: Why don’t we approach Sambara, lord of demons, and beg him for a pledge of safety.’
sn11.10:1.8: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, those hermits vanished from those leaf huts by the ocean and reappeared in Sambara’s presence.
sn11.10:1.9: Then those hermits addressed Sambara in verse:
sn11.10:2.2: to beg for a pledge of safety.
sn11.10:2.3: For you can give them what you wish,
sn11.10:3.3: Though you beg me for your safety,
sn11.10:4.1: ‘Though we beg you for our safety,
sn11.10:4.3: This is what we get from you:
sn11.10:4.4: may endless peril come to you!
sn11.10:5.1: Whatever kind of seed you sow,
sn11.10:5.2: that is the fruit you reap.
sn11.10:5.3: A doer of good gets good,
sn11.10:5.4: a doer of bad gets bad.
sn11.10:5.5: You have sown your own seed, friend,
sn11.10:6.1: Then those hermits, having cursed Sambara, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from Sambara’s presence and reappeared in those leaf huts by the ocean.
sn11.10:6.2: But after being cursed by the hermits, Sambara woke in alarm three times that night.”
